comment_text:
This is the third video in a series I'm doing on social media manipulation. Facebook is an extremely interesting case to study. They're the largest social media platform in the world and one could argue they've felt the pain of this stuff more than any other platform. I find it to be EXTREMELY interesting that they're transitioning to an ACTIVE position on misinformation as opposed to REACTIVE. I think it's super easy for the public to dismiss what facebook says because of their branding/trust issues.... but regardless of what you think about the company, they are one of the most attacked platforms in the world. Therefore, they're the most experienced people at countering this threat. At times it seems like they're getting their butts kicked, and at others it seems like they're winning. Facebook is not blameless, but directing all of our conversational energy towards the platform itself avoids a major issue, namely the people using the platform to do harm, or to inauthentically promote/discredit something.


The case of the fitness coach was disturbing. This is a well-known individual with millions of followers. She was clearly benefitting from inauthentic followers and commenters. Someone sympathetic to her clearly wrote the comments. The evidence was very damning in my opinion.... but ultimately I made the decision to blur our her page because attribution is difficult. What if someone purchased face comments on Smarter Every Day and said nice things, then framed me as the one who bought the comments? These are the types of things that undermine the very notion of social media integrity.


Another thought here. If you don't use facebook, you may be tempted to leave an anti-facebook comment. Totally cool. I'm not a heavy facebook user myself. I don't post my videos to facebook often because of their intellectual property policies. That being said, I've noticed that the tone of many of these comments has a "superiority" feel to them, with most of the disdain directed at the platform facebook itself. I think this is extremely interesting because its possible platform manipulation has affected how you feel about these platforms themselves. The people I met are trying very hard to make a high integrity platform, but it's clear they are fighting a huge corrupt industry, and in some cases a literal disinformation war. My language will be more charitable in the future.
It's awesome to see how invested these social media workers are at taking down these fake users! Keep up the good work!

I'm not very sympathetic to the argument that the engineers of Facebook were not responsible for the use of a tool they created that they did not understand (i.e. that the language and character set was not understood).  I am a licensed engineer in NC, USA.  We are not permitted to sign off on designs we do not understand of which the safety is therefore unknown.  You might say that the tool was used unsafely by a user and therefore not responsible and in fact, this is the argument usually given by any internet based company.  However, if you come to NC and call yourself an engineer or sell engineering services of which you have not investigated or described safe use to the end user (I don't believe most end user SW agreements discuss safe use defaulting to "it's all your fault and risk we promised nothing") or safeguarded against expected faults, you will get a visit from the inspectors (yes, there are full time engineering inspectors carrying the authority of the governor).  If you sell products or services in Japan, you will find you need to sign an extradition waiver before it is approved for sale.  If one did not understand the implications of doing business in a given country, don't do business there.

My two cents: It starts with the user. The user in combination with personal security measures. 
Multi-factor authentication is a good step forward. E-mail certificates that identify the sender and enable mail encryption augments it.  
But the problem with that is that it is complex to understand and to set up (and maintain). 

All that complexity needs to be engineered away from the user for it to make a dent. Protonmail is a good example of security by design, where the complexity is taken away from the user. Your barber's account probably wouldn't have been stolen if he would've had enabled MFA on his account, stuff like that. 
So democratising security by making it both simple and obligatory would prevent account hijacking and maybe even stop creation of fake accounts.

On the content side one could envision an obligation to post it only if it is signed with a certificate. If that certificate is issued by a trusted CA, then it's pretty much traceable and in situations that require it, could be revoked by this CA.

AND...
The human aspect (easily triggered, fight thy neighbour instincts) is all about the discussion on free speech. 
Those within that free speech debate usually forget the (probably biggest) consequence of it, namely 'the right to be offended'.

If we would understand that right, and act like it, then we probably wouldn't care if we stumbled upon at a text or vid that opposes whatever belief we hold personally.
However, regardless of one's position on whatever topic, we tend to place that outside of the realm of free speech, and lash out violently.
The better approach is to remember the old saying "sticks & stones" and move on.

This behavioural aspect may be unachievable. But the security thing is within the reach of engineers. Protonmail is a good initiative, I'd love to see Gmail and other providers follow their lead as a first step.

Fake Competitions, which exist just to harvest personal details, and are fairly obvious to anyone if you do a quick search for the organisations involved. They are just completely overlooked, and they 'don't go against facebook community standards', when reported.


Then there's fake games, which are immediately obvious by the animations and graphics to any game designer or graphics artist, to not be legitimate or functional game mechanisms, and then are obvious to anybody who clicks the link because if any game exists at the other end, it's a minimal copy/pasta simple engine thing that doesn't constitute anything like a full game, and the graphics are not only not of the quality advertised, but they are often of entirely different things altogether, and often the names are different when you get there, too, and seem often just designed to harvest personal details or even financial information. They are so obvious you could call it a brand. Yet when they are reported, they 'don't go against facebook community standards'.


Fake survey/pay-out sites, where a quick google + the word 'scam' will quickly reveal real reviews of people complaining about them being a scam almost immediately, though a lot of those start out legit for a year then go full-scam, but even once they've been scams for years, they 'don't go against facebook community standards', when reported.


Then there's the super-sale-awesome-items that are just re-branded from ebay at 4x the cost, or things like Wish where it starts at $2 in big flashy writing, for something worth $5-10, but by the time you've gone through several screens towards the checkout, it's now up to $15-$20 from little extra costs being added. These 'don't go against facebook community standards', when reported.


And ofcourse don't forget the "claim your free [gizmo here]", followed by 'just pay the postage', followed by tickboxes to pay for half the parts, plus a postage cost that's higher than the value of the item already. Yet these also 'don't go against facebook community standards', when reported.

As a web engineer myself, reducing this sort of thing is actually extremely simple, but no one does it because it increases the barrier to entry. Namely: 1) Making 2FA/2SV required greatly reduces the chance of accounts being hijacked and repurposed, 2) When accounts grow to a certain size, require additional personal identification (drivers license/passport, phone number, etc), 3) If an account is large and isn't verified, limit its reach until it is verified.

I think your best point is the one at the 18 minute mark. That's my professional field of expertise. Even in areas where we want the government making rules, the quick and dirty emergency fix is to dictate HOW things are done, not what result you want to get. This is bad lawmaking, and stifles innovation and is most open to exploit. Instead, IF you want a state to make rules, you usually want the rule to dictate the Result, but leave the method open to choice.


(easy example. In the 1950s they decided that we needed to see on roads, and dictated round sealed bulb halogen headlights with parabolic reflectors as the method. Those were the best tech at the time. Almost immediately, better headlights were developed in other shapes and using other methods of generating the light. We couldn't sell them here for a decade or two. It would have been better to dictate that drivers must at least be able to see a particular range. Or even dictating lumens at a particular distance in a particular wavelength.)


Regulators are most responsive to the needs and considerations of large organizations, because they can pay to staff lawyers and techs to study the issues. They are terrible at responding to the input of large groups of small institutions and individuals. You can pretty much guarantee that if the state makes a law about social media, the law will be designed from the standpoint and interests of the big companies, not their customers. It's a structural thing.

A point that I have heard that I find interesting is this. When does a platform like Facebook, which claims to be an open platform cross the line and become a publisher? A phone company like Verizon is not responsible for what is said  using their service. A traditional news outlet like the NY Times or Fox News is a publisher and is there for legally responsible for the content that is there. When does this manipulation on Facebook's side make Facebook a publisher responsible for the content published on their site? I see that manipulation is a problem on Facebook, but I am afraid of the solution which makes Facebook the great arbiter declaring one thing dangerous and another thing good. If a group posts things that are contrary to the values that Facebook has but are not inciting violence or pornographic, what is to stop Facebook from saying it is dangerous and we are going to hide this from the public? If they are the gate keepers it seems like they are liable as a company for what is on their site and it is no longer an open platform. This legally would be a steep cliff for Facebook. Even taking one small example of copyright photos. As a publisher Facebook could be sued for every photo posted that infringes the copyright protection. It is a dangerous platform in many ways, and is useful in many ways, but I see this become less and less of a truly free speech platform.

Hey Destin, I just wanted to thank you firstly for making this series. I can tell a lot of work was put into them.


On the topic of hacked accounts, I thought I would share a story of my experience.


One day I was at work and got an email notification from Instagram that I can now use a link to reset my password. I was concerned because I had not requested anything to reset. I immediately went to try and recover my account by trying to log in, only to find my password had been changed.


I then tried to go through Instagram to to report that I had been hacked to which they required me to reset a password through my email. Thing is, I tried to log into my email and my password was not working. This was all in the space of around 5 minutes. After my failed login attempt to my email, I got another email on a back-up email notifying me that my password for my main email account had been successfully changed. This is when things started getting crazy.


Straight away I knew that my password for my email had been compromised. I had a really good, long password so I found it strange that it had been hacked. I immediately changed my password on my back-up email and then tried to change my password for my main through the help of Google.


I finally got back into my account and in 10 minutes, they had changed my profile picture, and made 6 posts of half naked women telling people to click a link for Russian brides. Straight out of a movie.


The crazy thing is, when I got back in, I had noticed that they had tried to hack my account again WHILE I WAS USING IT! Only after about 40 mins of fighting I finally got my account back and it seems to have been okay since.


After that experience, I have put 2 factor authentication on every single account I own, and removed any stored login details from any site I have ever visited.


The world is a scary place ever since they realised they could target you with your own devices and you wouldn't know a thing.

I’m curious to what extent this type of manipulation occurs in the comments section of news websites. I often find myself reading what I think to be a relatively mild article on a political topic, only to scroll down and find a staggering number of negative comments in full opposition. While I understand that not everyone shares my views, it seems that the percentage of comments vehemently denouncing a concept or person is shockingly inconsistent with the actual spectrum of public opinion. I also get that those holding strong opinions are usually the most likely to voice them and that public opinion is particularly polarized at present, however I can’t help but feel suspicious that this is another outlet for targeted manipulation that isn’t often addressed. Did any of the experts you consulted with ever mention this platform? I consider it to be particularly harmful as those denouncing stories on local news sites are assumed to be actual neighbours and members of your community, so to find yourself in full opposition to their supposed views tempts the individual to make an emotional decision to blindly conform, without actually researching the facts.

So I just remembered to share this because this happened:
I follow the BBC, a recent article from them:
"Why I posed for a photo with anti-Islam activists"
(already fairly polarising... Thanks BBC)
The first comment I read:
"Nice gesture, but can Christians do the same in Islamic States"
Second comment:
"she probably never got attention in her misearable life was desperate for an opportunity"
Both of these comments aim to polarise and anger the readers. They both have the most attention, with hundreds of likes and several comments.
Are these comments from real people?
Well, the first guy seems legit, but again maybe not... He seems to post a lot of content that gets very little attention from his friends.
Also, most of the stuff he posts is fairly angry, maybe he is just an angry young kid, maybe not...
The second person was 100% a bot and not even a very good one, there was 0 info on her page, no friends, no photos, no workplace, no school, nothing about her at all, just a profile pic of a young Indian girl who seems nice.
So, I went further... Not only do these angry first comments almost certainly come from bots, but most of the angry reaction comments do as well...
One of the angry reaction comments comes from a girl who only has three posts on her wall, and has no friends and no history.
Another of the angry commenters has no friends and no history, and only posts angry memes on his wall that get likes and comments from the same people who ALSO seem to be bots!
One consistent 'liker' of his 'content' is the typical catfish type account with a beautiful girl who only posts pictures of herself. This account also has no friends and no history.
Okay, now for the worst thing I've found:
Another 'liker' of this angry persons 'content' is a dead woman.
I checked her page and the last actual post was an update of her profile pic with comments from her friends and family saying how great she was...

Federal prosecutors are conducting a criminal investigation into data deals Facebook struck with some of the world’s largest technology companies, intensifying scrutiny of the social media giant’s business practices as it seeks to rebound from a year of scandal and setbacks.
A grand jury in New York has subpoenaed records from at least two prominent makers of smartphones and other devices, according to two people who were familiar with the requests and who insisted on anonymity to discuss confidential legal matters. Both companies had entered into partnerships with Facebook, gaining broad access to the personal information of hundreds of millions of its users.
The companies were among more than 150, including Amazon, Apple, Microsoft and Sony, that had cut sharing deals with the world’s dominant social media platform. The agreements, previously reported in The New York Times, let the companies see users’ friends, contact information and other data, sometimes without consent. Facebook has phased out most of the partnerships over the past two years.
“We are cooperating with investigators and take those probes seriously,” a Facebook spokesman said in a statement. “We’ve provided public testimony, answered questions and pledged that we will continue to do so.”

I'm sorry Dustin, I understand very well that the complexity of the problem from an engineering perspective is huge, and I do believe all these people are trying really hard to overcome these issues. However, facebook is not an essential service for society. It may connect people, be entertaining, provide a platform for advertising and promotion of small business and so on, but none of it is of utmost importance to a given population - or at least shouldn't be.

Now when you own such a system that provides these amenities but also enables a mechanism that can potentially lead to genocide, you have to shut it down. You don't wait for government action - because it may even benefit of your mechanism to reach its interests - you shut it down yourself. Unfortunately facebook isn't hold accountable for the deaths that are indirectly caused (directly enabled) by their platform, and thus they're not directly considered in a financial cost-benefit analysis. The moral question is then reduced to: "would I rather keep profiting by engaging in means that potentially lead to the death of others, or stop engaging in those means altogether?". Facebook reactive countermeasures necessarily requires some kind of harm in the first place, and until they can effectively prevent misuse preemptively, they should take their product out of the market, especially in foreign markets, where it threatens delicate and intricate social equilibrium from nations it has never heard of (let alone tried to comprehend them).

Your effort to inform people about the difficulty of the task and raise skepticism is venerable but, honestly, all it does is drive away the attention of actors that permit these atrocities to happen by providing the service. I joined Facebook in 2008 because my wife wanted to be "Facebook married". As an engineer, I became interested in this new technology and how it could be used.

The next year Facebook introduced Groups; so, I had the idea of creating a Town Facebook Group as a member run town Wiki/newspaper. The issue I had seen were there was lots of fun events I missed that I didn't know about; so, I figured a town Facebook Group could address this. I created one and it floundered (I am an Engineer, my social connection are quite limited); but, a couple of random sparks got it started. One example was our Town Memorial Day Parade (which was the central annual town event). It started raining, some of the instruments were getting wet, the parade hadn't started and nobody knew what was going on. The next thing I knew my group was the that information source and it went viral (at least in my limited space).

The Group is setup as in Open Group but with required membership approval. I do this to keep out people that shouldn't be there. I manage it using a simple set of published rules I created early on. I only address issues when there is a clear violation of the stated rules. The group is now 10 years old, I try my best to keep bad actors out. Currently there are now about 12,000 members. That number is small in the Facebook world; but, for me it is a lot.

I has been such an interesting journey to see the dynamics of a group like this where people have such polarized views. As an admin, people expect me to do so many things (like to police fake/duplicate accounts; but, on that I forward them to Facebook. I can only do so much. I have tried my best to keep it to my original vision (even though I no longer live there); but, it is REALLY hard to keep up with. Sometimes things you create grow to meet the need you saw; but then, you go - OH MY GOSH, WHAT DO I DO NOW.

It is interested to see a peek behind the scenes of the bigger picture of that at Facebook and see the challenges they face.

I've been working on a Cyber Ethics paper based on this topic, asking the question whether it is ethical for companies like facebook and twitter to blanket ban people based on their political views. Needless to say it turned out to be a much more complicated topic than that, and thankfully the paper is a semester long project. One of the main crux's for me is that we are trying to fix a problem that is a symptom of the systems already in place. If we think about it, the internet has centralized itself into a few platforms like Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, etc whereas before these sites you had to go to individual forums to find information or opinions. One of the nice things about the centralization is that we all are on a few platforms and networking becomes super easy, but the problem is that we are all on these few platforms and dissemination of information has outpaced our ability to fight bad information.

It's a very interesting topic and I was super excited to see your video series pop up when I was in the earlier stages of my paper. I have actually incorporated some of the things that I learned here to help develop a more consistent paper. You are also right, this is going to be the main issue for our generation. There is so much riding on how we handle the problem of fake news and human impersonators, I really think this is where we should be putting much of our intellectual focus as far as cyber-security goes.

1:43 - Several unrelated things there. First, they don't really "code in English" as much as in C++ and so on. The language used for the function names and comments is kind of irrelevant, it doesn't affect the data being processed. Things have gone so far that I've developed a kind of "internet-phobia". For example: I've deleted all my social media accounts (except Youtube) and I have 2 different phones. On one phone I don't use any mobile games or apps other than selected ones that came pre-installed + 2 or 3 apps that I REALLY need for work and to handle banking. This is my main-phone where I keep all my contacts, email-account and other personal things such as photos, notes, project-plannings etc. It also has a strict setup of bookmarks, which I (after closely examinating all terms and policys) consider safe and trustworthy sites that are essential for my everyday life. This phone NEVER visits any other webpages or uses any search engines (I know this because I programmed my own web-browser and made it incapable of navigating out of the "bookmark trust-group"), it also ONLY connects to the cellular-network and never has bluetooth, wi-fi or any other connectivity activated. Then I have another phone, this one is never connected to the same network as my main phone (to avoid passing any potentially malicious apps to it) and I use this one for Googling things, browse around on sites I've not visited before and to try out different apps.

This way I can be sure that I always keep my main phone and personal integrity fairly safe, while still being able to use any app and not having to worry while browsing the internet :)

The example given is an excellent one. They refer to it as "pornography" despite very clearly talking about nudity. Nudity is not, never has been, and never will be, pornography. The view that nudity is disgusting, disturbing, or should be forbidden is itself an extremely radical and anti-human viewpoint. It's one which is only very recently developed in society, and which has only spread since the 1990s. Even the most radically puritanical societies of the past viewed nudity as harmless, and usually unavoidable in day to day life (depending on how far back you are going). The attempt to redefine 'pornography' as 'nudity' and the attempt to redefine 'nudity' as 'wearing revealing clothing like underwear or bathing suits' is a novel attempt at social engineering. While in the past you would need to make a reasoned argument to human beings to try to convince them to hide their filthy, immoral body parts, Facebook, Apple, Google, and the other various companies are using their control over the means of communication to technologically alter social norms and morality. After all, if tomorrow everyone in the world woke up and said 'wait, 100% of human beings have bodies and it is childish and senseless to be concerned about seeing them' - how would they talk about this revelation? Any attempt they made to show people that they actually believed this would be instantly curtailed by the censorbots. No one would know that the rest of the entire world agreed with them.

Even if you agree that human bodies are a disgusting, offensive burden that the human species has to bear in private, the willingness to use this power should be terrifying to everyone. The American Heart Association believed that they saw in the medical research a correlation between saturated fats in a persons diet and heart disease. Being in the position they were, they were able to circumvent needing to educate and appeal to the publics reason in order to attempt to change peoples diet. They used government regulations and programs instead. And they accomplished their goal of reducing the portion of Americans daily caloric intake coming from saturated fats by 15%. The problem, however, is that when companies removed saturated fats from their food, they tasted like cardboard and no one wanted them. So they added salt and sugar to restore flavor, which reignited public interest in the foods. It ended up radically increasing the overall caloric intake of most of the public. Which led to an obesity epidemic, a diabetes epidemic, and yes, a heart disease epidemic. And then they found out that saturated fats were never really quite as dangerous as feared. But by that point, their unintended consequences were already killing hundreds of thousands of people a year. And while you can correct having told someone something wrong with some more education, changing large-scale social behavior back isn't something which can be done. The negative consequences will continue to wreak suffering and death for a generation at least. Are we so absolutely dead certain that the human body is something we evolved to have be a danger to ourselves that we're willing to accept all the unintended consequences of barring it completely from public discourse? When most children already reach adulthood having never seen more than a handful of actual real normal human beings nude (pornography does not feature normal human beings, it features statistically abnormal examples of beauty) and they believe their own bodies to be abnormally ugly, are we going to be comfortable with the rise in suicides, body dysmorphic disorder, etc? Something which could be cured by simply seeing a few normal people naked (especially in person as used to occur in school showers or gym or pool changing rooms but which is now avoided almost completely) can, and does, kill in addition to inflicting people with a profound lack of understanding and perspective on the human form. Is this preferable to having to see human bodies?

Listening to Nathaniel, it sounds to me like there are 2 aspects to defending against Social manipulation. Automation, which companies like facebook have control over, and education, which is what' you're helping to contribute to.


I also work in the realm of cybersecurity, and (very) often, our last line of defense, is the 'end user', the person ultimately being exposed to the potentially malicious content. As you keep saying, with counter, and counter-counter measures, the battle to automatically remove malicious content will never be over, but in the end, users are the ones being exposed to it.


In my company, we have mandatory Phishing\Malicious content training, which seems to be (at least somewhat) effective. But I fear mass-scale multi-billion person training would be infeasible if facebook\twitter\ect were to try to enforce similar training to users. While your videos are hitting the nail on the head, it is only reaching a small subset of the users actually using these platforms.


Do you think these social media companies have an obligation train their users in a similar way? They'd certainly have the capability to distribute such training, but as with all cybersecurity, Something is either convenient, secure, or somewhere in-between. SM companies adopting a more secure position would mean a less convenient experience for everyone, and therefore less users, a pretty scary catch22. While SM companies are trying to maximize user engagement, and therefore profit, they are also pressured (correctly) to decrease malicious engagement, at the cost of legitimate engagement.


I guess my point in the end, is that SM companies that take social manipulation seriously, are essentially combating themselves, and it worries me to think that a company that decides not to take such issues seriously, will have a financial advantage over the ones who do. We see this somewhat already with Youtube censoring; The more Youtube tries to ensure its content is 'suitable', and the more legitimate accounts that get affected by takedowns or similar censoring, the more users are motivated to find another platform that isn't affected by the same issues. I fear a future where non-regulated FB, TW, IG, RD, YT, ect all exist, with the owners not caring about any of this.

Me and some friends run the Instagram account for our band, each one has access on their phone.

After a few days of seeing weird stuff in the main feed, one of us saw that we were following hundreds of weird accounts: models, fitness, companies, you name it.

We kept unfollowing them but they were hundreds and Instagram doesn't have a friendly interface for this. We changed the password and it surprisingly kept happening.

Turns out, one of us had installed Netflix from an apk he downloaded because Google Play said his device was incompatible.

He uninstalled it and things went back to normal. It was obviously full of malware.

But I can only imagine the possibly thousands of fake comments and likes our band's Instagram left around, and the insane amount of people this must be happening to right now without them realizing.

These people are light hours ahead of us.

But Facebook, Google, Twitter etc... do share an important part of the blame when it come to the increasing polarization of the ideological scene and the rise of the extremes: they use content personalization.

Their algorithms are optimized with the single goal of maximizing audience retention, offering content that is most likely to grab our attention.
Unfortunately, that usually means content that agrees with our previously held opinions and beliefs, creating a "filter bubble", where all we see is people agreeing with us, and are given the false impression that our viewpoint is universal, and must therefore be absolutely valid.

Over time, that sort of intellectual isolation unavoidably makes ideologies drifts towards more extreme views, as all you see of the "other side" is the caricature made by those who share your views and are equally isolated in that bubble.

Loved the video. I work on many of these problems, and I'd actually argue I work on the root of this problem, which is digital identity (or Self Sovereign Identity as we call it). I have a handful of friends at Facebook and the other social media giants and I don't hold the failure to solve these problems against them, however, their companies can fundamentally NOT solve this problem (at least in a way that doesn't create equally bad or worse problems). This is because of the business model. It is one that attempts to monetize something that isn't theirs, identity and reputation. This isn't always clear at first when you look at the situation, but it is ultimately what it all resolves to. Advertising is based on impressions and implicit in that is that the impressions are on unique humans. Facebook cannot physically validate the personhood of every user so they do it programmatically, which they are struggling with. This leads to an inefficient arms race scenario. There then is a second, but related problem. Facebook does not have any user facing concept of reputation, and for good reason. Reputation systems are notoriously hard to get right and in most cases end up being incredibly oppressive (Facebook does have an internal concept of user reputation though, which has its own dangers). However, reputation is the key to scaling identity systems and interaction online in a way that is resilient against manipulation and dishonesty. IRL you cannot stand on a street corner and yell fake news into crowds of people WITHOUT incurring repuational cost. Reputation is the way we have always scaled scaled human interaction up until now and it has largely worked because everyone gets to run and update their own reputation algorithms on everyone else in a way that accounts for context. This is essentially what we are referring to when we tell someone to not be so judgemental. The difference in risk between a decentralized, open source, bottom up reputation system and a top down, opaque, and rigid one is incredibly critical, in fact it is the difference between the world we want and 1984. So , why doesn't facebook build that reputation system? Well, because to build an open source, decentralized reputation system Facebook would have to cede the control of users' data back to them, if they don't, then it is centralized and if they do then it allows users to withhold their data/reputation from Facebook while still having the ability to interact with their peers directly and the result is the plummeting of Facebook's ad revenue. Facebook relies on being able to hyper target on the basis of having access to highly detailed data on billions of people. That would go away. There are many other concepts to explore here and I have oversimplified a number of things but suffice it to say that we have what is likely a binary choice in our future: one where Facebook or other centralized platforms accrue power and increase oppression in desperation to solve this problem OR one where Facebook, Google, and even governments lose control over their customer/user/constituent's identity and reputation leading to their demise.

Watched all three of the videos in this series, and here are my 2 cents:

For a person claiming to be fighting the division in society, fighting the artificial "us vs. them" divide, you are simply redefining the "us" and the "them" parts and actually enforcing and expanding the division -- in your narrative all bad behavior/examples seem to come from one specific direction, all the good comes from a different and also quite specific direction, trust one and doubt the other, is this not more of what you are trying to prevent?

I'm all for the freedom and transparency, but this narrative is not the way to go, IMHO.

To be constructive, you do make some valid points: cross-checking is good practice, knowing about and working with one's confirmation bias is good advice, informing the viewers of attack vectors is good and you should have gone deeper on this, especially after mentioning a very specific example(s) of account hijacking in this video, but you did not address the topic at all, nor do you touch on the conflict of interest that companies like modern social networks have with most of their user-base, etc. ..."common sense", or lack thereof, in information and information theory is a big problem we face today and a subject worth pursuing, but you're not only avoiding it but rather making it worse by "painting" sides and asserting trust or mistrust...

Again, IMHO, this is a step backward for what I've come to expect from your channel, yes, at least part of the motivation seems (hopefully) to be sincere, but here there is quite a bias...

While I agree some content should be 'flagged' as potentially harmful/misleading I don't think they should be removed. First; if we don't know a threat exists because it has been censored how are we to protect ourselves from similar attack elsewhere? Second; in an age where our liberties are constantly under attack limiting freedom of speech is counter productive and such acts are already weaponized against We The People. See Apparatus of Repression.

That said and in reference to 'foreign actors' it is the duty of NSA/CIA to guard our national firewalls - the fact that such things even make it through Echelon/Prism/Carnivore/etc. calls into question the honor of said alphabet soup agencies. Foreign propaganda is a matter of National Security; however - US companies must not be complicit in the censorship of common people nor should such actions be given the silent nod of approval by the stewardship structure and political actors.

The internet at large is a free speech zone so let's keep it that way and relegate these Orwellian ideologies into oblivion. Knowledge is power; to deny the people knowledge is to deny them their power - to subjugate the know nothings to the will of know it alls. Imagine SmarterEveryDay the evolution of such ideology and acceptance thereof; how long before it is exploited - like all else has - against us?

If you need examples of such; look at the media blackout surrounding Standing Rock in 2016. Also pay attention to France and the Yellow Vest protests which have been ongoing for 24 weeks; heavy media blackout going on there. State actors are exploiting technology to hide their crimes against humanity.

I would say to the development teams of future applications - take a look at how video games (MMORPGS) are handled as social environments. Below I will try my best to outline the pros and cons of the game method.

# THE PAY WALL
• The pay wall: a new user is prohibited from progressing or engaging with other users unless they pay a fee.
This can provide income for service fees, future projects and profit. It also acts as a verification method for age and
location. Moreover it can act as an investment, for example , if someone spends $100.00 on an account over a 
period of several years - they may not want to loose it if they break the rules.

it's not all-good though, asking users for a sign-up fee can encourage hacking of funds or accounts to acquire a  
"free" account for exploit or money to provide for the fee. You may also see selling of accounts on the black market
and account sharing to bypass this aspect. 

# SOCIAL PEERS
• Social peers (A.K.A. Friends) are people inside the environment who know your individual personality and can vouch  
for you. This is an often overlooked spect but plays a role every-day. Often the first notice of a hacked account is  
made by a friend of the user who notices that the person isn't acting like they normally do. If you've ever encountered 
a game with a justice system ( judge jury act) having a friend to vouch for you can make all the difference in the 
world when we are trying to figure out who is responsible or what happened. Take a while and think of all the 
different ways friends can help in this sort of situation.

Again- we have downsides. For instance, say all your friends are bad-apples and encourage you to do bad things , 
well that's kind of what this video is about - isn't it? It's usually up to the user in games to acquire friends and 
connections. But what Facebook and other platforms have done is automate the finding of fiends and directly 
connects you to everything that shares a remote common theme. You have little control over who your friends are.

# CLEAR RULES
• Clear rules that are not only enforced but encouraged by the community. Yes it's easier to bust people when the chess board can warp into anything ( I yelled "WHAT NOW" at my screen at 17:40) but remember some of the playing pieces on the board are also good and decent who are going along for the ride. Clear rules gives those people who want to live by the book a guideline to follow (e.g. do this and you will be [ok]) that's all they need.

Sometimes you run into people who don't understand why we don't have a big list of things you CAN do verses only having a vague list of things that are general rules of thumb and occasionally listing punishments for examples on things you CAN'T do. I say this aspect was covered well in this video and (if I can remember) will send people here instead of attempting to explain the difference. But we always will have misunderstandings.

I like to use 'is the sky is blue' analogy here.. What if we have two people talking and you hear one of the people say "is the sky is blue" and the other one responds with "well duh, its because of how the light....ect ect" .. then the first person replies " it was a rhetorical question... " This is the kind of thing that is hard to distinguish even for humans. we can't write the solution because we don't know what it is! Quick- tell me what it is so I can write it down!

# COMMON LANGUAGE
• this brings us to common language - with games, everything has to be easy to interact with. everything from how you control your character to how you interact with other players. With chat based games, language is an obvious issue. You can't have people talking in an alternate language that your moderators can't read.

Turns out this solution was implemented by mistake (I think) when regain optimization was more heavily used with online games to improve connection speed. Because people who lived closer to each other most likely had a better connection and spoke the same langue this was a decent move! (this comment is not sponsored by VPN :p)

I have to say from experience of trying to deal with systems not written in English - it's a nightmare to even figure out what is going on in the code. the solution to that was they hired a technician that knew the language and he would amend the source code from time to time. they would pass a big list of things that they wanted changed and he would go-ahead and update.  

I'm telling you right now it would have been better to re-write the entire thing from scratch. The problem is you can't judge the success of an app - you need to balance recourses right. Can't spend 10 of the 11 years in development making it exploit proof for a game that doesn't take off. in other words best to make open ended in that regard!

This is so frustrating. My first instinct was to share this video on FB. Then I remembered, it's useless. With how FB suppresses YouTube links, very few of my friends will even see it. It's so maddening, because I can't share the information that can combat fake news - not in a way where it'll be seen.

I know big companies pay for the boosts, but most individual creators can't afford that. I mean, I had to install a Chrome extension to force FB to show me "Most Recent" automatically, versus the "Top Stories" that FB insists we all view. I did this so I could see the pages and people I like that haven't paid for the boost. Well, that and I was tired of seeing the same 20 people in my feed. 😂

So FB, in their foundational mission statement (make all the money), is still directly contributing to the problem. While all these measures they're taking to combat misinformation are helpful, they're only band-aids. The manipulation really is subtle.  We talk about it as a threat posed by hostile entities but even local parties and governments participate.  One of the most insidious manipulations I saw in 2016 were these partisan meme groups.  I'd say 2/3rds or more of my face book friends were subscribed and sharing these memes because they found them funny. They'd often have short blurbs pointing out a "hypocrisy" by listing "facts" or something.  But pretty much every one of them contained misinformation in them.  Often even outright lies.  Thing is they spread like a disease and because they mixed in humor with extremism people didn't see how they were swaying their opinions.   In the same way Fox News intentionally misrepresented the Green New Deal until their audience wholly believed it was about banning cows and air travel.. these memes do similar.   After awhile all that extremism really did take root though.  I actually ended up leaving facebook over it... as I couldn't watch my friends and family turn into angry monsters anymore.  I hope things have gotten better.... realistically though I doubt it.
